title: The psychological toll of a pandemic, and the societal problems it has highlighted
content: Psychiatrist Paul Conti, M.D. discusses the impact of the fear and uncertainty surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic and the resulting stress, anxiety, and trauma it may impart on the population. Paul examines how this situation has highlighted the challenges we face at the societal level as well as the individual level.

title: Paul's personal experience with a presumptive case of COVID-19
content: Paul’s personal experience with a presumptive case of COVID-19 [2:15];

title: The lasting effects of this pandemic on society
content: Through the lens of trauma, Paul’s overall take on the lasting effects of this pandemic on society [4:30];

title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Factors Contributing to Chronic Illness
content: Robert Sapolsky provides insight into the factors that contribute to chronic illness.

title: The Impact of Stress on Chronic Illness, Dementia, Depression, and More
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the physiology of a stress response and why it’s ingrained in our DNA.

title: Individual Variation in the Response to Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about individual variation in the response to stress and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: The Impact of Stress on Memory and Health
content: Robert Sapolsky discusses the role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia, as well as the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: The Impact of Stress on Cancer, Atherosclerosis, Dementia, Addiction, and Depression
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Paul's personal experience with a presumptive case of COVID-19
content: In early March, Paul and his family each has some symptoms that are common one of COVID-19. They were not tested, but Paul is fairly certain they each had it. Paul had the most severe symptoms including: Felt extremely hot with alternating bouts of terrible chills, awful headache, deep nausea, and shortness of breath.

title: Through the lens of trauma, Paul’s overall take on the lasting effects of this pandemic on society
content: Paul is frustrated with the fact that this situation we’re in seemed very predictable. We’ve been paving the way for trauma to happen both medically and socioeconomically, says Paul. And I think where I ring my hands and gnash my teeth is the idea that maybe we won’t learn from this and I’m worried that we…could then sort of traumatize ourselves out of existence.

title: The imperative to unite as a species given the isolating and suspicious nature of an invisible enemy
content: We internalize this in a way that is more and more isolating and I think historically just makes people very suspicious of one another. Paul believes we have a social structure that searches for an enemy. Paul stresses the importance of uniting as a species rather than trying to blame others or fear that “others” are the problem. Paul says, “I don’t think we do right now” …  because it’s much easier to align around a common enemy. But I think we can, says Paul.

title: The indigent population and the affluent population—The commonalities and differences in how both populations have been affected
content: The commonalities and differences in how both populations have been affected.

title: The Societal Threat of Disease
content: This is a gigantic medical problem. It is a social problem. It is an economic problem. When you add those things together. . . it becomes a societally threatening medical, socioeconomic problem, and we haven’t had that before.

title: Impact on Indigent Population
content: For the more indigent population… It’s added desperation on top of desperation. Half the population in this country couldn’t survive and move forward from $500 unexpected costs or a $500 shortfall. Paul says that this subsection of the society has been sort of left behind. And this is just exacerbating their situation.

title: Impact on Affluent Population
content: For the more affluent population… We have become prisoners of the insecurity that we have generated from, for example, the way “news” is presented. It affects people even who say have enough economic means but still have this pervasive feeling that there’s always, always, always something to fear. The fear drives suffering b/c it starts to spiral out of control and people get obsessive with negative thoughts that run  over and over and over. What is uniting us is this pervasive insecurity. And then these parts of our brain that want to keep us safe go into overdrive and inadvertently make us feel so much more vulnerable.

title: Demoralization Spanning the Population
content: The prevailing feeling of demoralization spanning the population. Paul identifies these feelings of desperation as a sense of demoralization. This sense of demoralization comes from the idea that no matter what you do and how hard you work…  you can be vulnerable anyway. Paul also thinks that we’ve lost our way from a leadership standpoint adding to this problem.

title: Lingering Psychological Effects on Healthcare Workers
content: Paul says we have been stretching people to the limit. They’re working in a system that doesn’t know them, care about them, value them. We’ve allowed the systems to evolve into this compounded ignorance where we can’t take care of the people who are supposed to take care of us, and they know that and they’ve known that for a long time, and they’re seeing it come to the forefront. Due to the trauma, we will most likely see a rise in things like alcoholism, domestic violence, suicide, and people giving up and walking away from things that are important to them.

title: Preparing for Future Disease Outbreaks
content: Thought experiment: If there’s SAR-CoV-3 in 2030, what do we need to have in place to do a better job than we might be doing today? What we need is an “alliance of common sense” says Paul.

title: The Need for Truth in Society
content: A group of influential people should prioritize looking at truth and treat the current state of our social, medical, and economic systems as not okay. This pandemic could be a catalyst for changing the way people think about science, truth, and logic. We need an alliance of common sense where people agree to look at the logic and look at the facts when they disagree even if it goes against their current beliefs. We need to establish sources that are arbiters of truth outside of politics that are arbiters of what’s actually true.

title: Humility vs Hubris in Dealing with Uncertainty
content: As a society, we struggle with being able to say 'I don’t know'. Instead, people will come up with things to say they know (hubris). But it’s incredibly important to have the humility to say I don’t know. Admitting that we don’t know engenders humility, the humility that makes us careful. Hubris leads people to just declare that they know. And there’s a recklessness to that.

title: Self-Care During the Pandemic
content: Connection to others can be an antidote to trauma. Rather than money and success, this is a time to find things that are truly meaningful.

title: The forthcoming challenge of reintegrating back into the world when the quarantines lift
content: We’re going to see more anxiety, more obsessiveness, more panic, more agoraphobia (fear of being outside of the home) we’re going to see more of the unhealthy coping mechanisms like drugs and alcohol We’re going to see more of the unintended results of that, like depression and accidents. Because there is nothing there to prove that you are safe This is about trauma and how this pandemic is traumatizing us and how we paved the way for the trauma of it to be so bad and we need to change that.

title: An urgent need for change which must come through individuals seeking absolute truth and taking action
content: The common theme: “Those of us who sit here in the peanut gallery who are not in a position of leadership are going to have to sort of become the movement of change. In other words, it’s not enough to just sit around and pontificate about this stuff. We are going to at some point have to do something about it. We’re going to have to take some sort of action.” “What we have to do is really unpalatable things. Stand against the status quo, enter into arenas that are politically charged, enter into minefields knowing there’s something unpleasant is going to happen.”

title: Dr. Paul M. Conti's Medical Background
content: Dr. Paul M. Conti is a graduate of Stanford University School of Medicine. He completed his training at Stanford and at Harvard, where he served as Chief Resident.

title: Dr. Paul M. Conti's Practice
content: Dr. Conti is a general psychiatrist, treating all aspects of both mental illness and the impact of life stressors. His practice includes use of medications and psychotherapy, and he also routinely treats complex cases, co-occurring alcohol and drug issues, and does neuropsychiatric assessments.
